Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Molecular Regulation of Cortical Synapse Development
Award.AbstractNarration: Proper brain development involves elaboration of a network containing billions of neurons. This complex process requires the precise initiation, and subsequent maturation, of trillions of synaptic connections between these cells. This research project aims to improve our understanding of the cellular and molecular mechanisms that regulate the developmental maturation of cortical synapse structure and function. These studies focus on the role of a unique neurotransmitter receptor, the n-methyl-d-aspartate (NMDA) receptor. NMDA receptors, which sense glutamate released from other neurons are known to regulate changes in synaptic strength that underlie learning and memory in the adult brain. However, the role of these receptors during synapse development is less well understood. Interestingly, the protein subunit composition of these receptors is tightly controlled during development. NMDA receptors are heteromultimeric structures formed by association of two NR1 and two NR2 subunits. Heightened synaptogenesis, during late embryogenesis and early postnatal life, corresponds with the exclusive expression and incorporation of NR2B subunits to this receptor complex. These studies apply current techniques in genetics, molecular biology and electrophysiology to probe the role of these unique NR2B-containing receptors during a postnatal cortical circuit patterning. Mentorship support is provided for both undergraduate and graduate students. In addition this project aims to promote career opportunities in neuroscience and/or biomedical research to students at minority-serving schools in Louisiana through the initiation of an annual training course in Neurobiology research. This course will be held each spring at the Louisiana Universities Marine Consortium (LUMCON) DeFelice Marine Station in Cocodrie Louisiana.

CAREER: Molecular Regulation of Cortical Synapse Development

Benjamin Hall, Tulane University

Project Outcomes Report

 

There were two goals of this CAREER award:

1)    to improve understanding of the cellular and molecular mechanisms involved in brain development.

2)    to promote the careers of under-represented minority students with an interest in neuroscience from across the Louisiana University system.

The first goal was accomplished by combining techniques in mouse genetics with electrophysiology, cellular imaging and biochemistry. They resulted in the identification of a critical cellular signaling cascade that homeostatically regulates synaptic strength in cortical neurons. This pathway, which involves activaiton of a unique set of glutamate sensing neurotransmitter receptors in the brain, GluN2B subunit-containing NMDA receptors, we showed to be critical for normal cortical function and expression of social behaviors. Interestingly, from these data we hypothesize this siganling pathway might be critically involved in mediating the rapid anti-depressant actions of low-dose ketamine, which is an NMDA receptor antagonist. This hypothesis, which we arrived at through the pure basic research program funded here, is now under investigation with the goal of advancing therapies in treatment resistant depressed patients. 

The research funding also supported, either fully or partially, the publication of five peer-reviewed articles in major neuroscience journals including Neuron and The Journal of Neuroscience. In addition, the support funded graduate students from my lab to participate and present each year (2010-2014) at the Society for Neuroscience Annual meeting. 

The second goal was accomplished through financial support of a course called Neurobiology at LUMCON, which the PI developed and ran at the Louisiana Universities Marine Consortium (LUMCON). This two-week long course trained undergraduate students from across Louisiana in cutting edge neuroscience research techniques including electrophysiology and fluorescence-based imaging. Students were recruited through a competitive application process and given a stipend to attend the course, which was held each year at the LUMCON field station in Cocodrie, LA in May. The course provided hands on training and small group lectures. In addition, through direct interaction with daily visiting professors from Tulane, LSU, as well as keynote speakers from the NIH, HHMI’s Janelia Farm and Harvard, the course also provided attending students with ongoing faculty support for their careers. Description and updates from the LUMCON course can be found on Facebook at the Neurobiology at LUMCON page.
